summary: Responsive single-page Valentine invitation webpage with initial network error screen and retry/refresh transition into a Valentine invite featuring YES/NO interactions, confetti/hearts effects, dynamic gradient background, and puppy mood changes; plus added visual polish extras (pulsing glows, floating hearts, fade-ins, and subtle shadows/bounce animations).
architectural_notes: Implement as a responsive single-page HTML/CSS/JS experience with state-based screen transitions and animations (CSS transitions + JS-driven effects like confetti/hearts).
Ensure the NO button’s random positions are clamped to the viewport/safe area so it never renders off-screen.
Keep added visual polish effects lightweight (CSS animations where possible) and avoid distracting from the core YES/NO interactions.

existing_features.title: Create a responsive single-page UI with two screens: (1) an initial “network error” screen and (2) a Valentine invitation screen, with a smooth, natural transition between them.
Implement the initial network error screen UI with a friendly retry message and a centered refresh button.
Implement the Valentine invitation screen UI with the exact main question and subtitle text, and place two buttons labeled exactly “yes” and “no” directly below the message.
Add a puppy image above the Valentine invitation message; on each press of the “no” button, update the puppy image to a different picture that becomes progressively sadder.

Implement “no” button behavior: only after the user clicks “no”, the button should jump to a new position on the screen; this should continue in a loop on every “no” click until the user clicks “yes”.
On each “no” click, change the soft gradient background to different soft colors while maintaining an aesthetic soft red & white theme.

Implement “yes” button behavior: reveal the exact message “now u're my personal marad, no backoffing”, hide both YES and NO buttons smoothly after 1 second, and trigger a soft confetti effect that lasts 10 seconds then disappears.
Add a heart shower visual effect behind/within the revealed message area: soft red hearts that appear one after another like a shower when the “yes” reveal message is shown.

Apply the requested overall design system: soft gradient background, rounded edges, subtle shadows, consistent font across all text, and a sweet/soft/playful aesthetic in red & white across both screens.

Introduce one coherent visual theme direction (colors, typography, layout styling) that matches a sweet, soft, playful Valentine aesthetic (red & white), and apply it consistently across the page without adding extra product features.
Add the required static image assets (puppy mood sequence) under frontend/public/assets/generated and render them directly from the frontend (not via backend).

When the invitation is in the accepted state (after clicking “yes”), display a happiest puppy image/GIF in the reveal area instead of continuing to show the current sad puppy from the NO-click sequence.
Make the sad puppy images on the Valentine invitation screen loop on repeated presses of the “no” button (cycle through the sad variants repeatedly rather than stopping at the last sad image).

Update the Valentine invitation screen so that after the user clicks the “no” button once, the “no” button starts jumping to new random positions on the screen automatically (i.e., continues moving on its own) and keeps doing so in a loop until the user clicks the “yes” button. Keep the puppy image sequence looping on repeated “no” interactions (do not stop at the last sad image).

Update the Valentine invitation screen so that after the user clicks the “no” button once, the “no” button automatically keeps jumping to new random positions on its own in a loop until the user clicks “yes” (the button should continue to be clickable while moving).

Constrain the automatically moving “no” button positions so the button never renders off-screen on common viewport sizes (mobile and desktop), accounting for the button’s width/height and safe padding from edges.

Add an animated happy puppy asset and use it as the initial puppy shown on the Valentine invitation screen before any “no” clicks (while still keeping the existing sad puppy loop behavior on subsequent “no” interactions and the existing happiest puppy GIF on “yes” acceptance).
Add tiny floating heart bubbles drifting upward in the background of the Valentine invitation screen (and keep them subtle so they do not distract from the main card content).
Add a soft pulsing glow outline around the puppy image on the invitation screen.
Add a smooth fade-in animation for the main Valentine question text when the invitation screen is shown.
Add a very soft shadow/grounding effect under the moving “no” button so it looks playful while it jumps around.
Add a subtle idle wiggle/bounce animation to the initial happy puppy (before any NO clicks) to make it feel more alive.
Add a small sparkle ‘pop’ animation around the puppy each time its mood image changes (e.g., on each NO click and when switching to the accepted happiest puppy on YES).

Make the background feel slightly more alive by adding a very gentle pulse/shift effect to the existing gradient background without changing the existing gradient color set or NO-click gradient cycling behavior.
Add a soft glow around the main Valentine question text on the invitation screen (keep it readable and tasteful).

new_feature_requests.summary: Initial 'network error' screen with friendly retry message and centered refresh button that transitions to the Valentine invitation screen
Valentine invitation UI: main question text, subtitle, consistent typography, soft red/white aesthetic, rounded corners, subtle shadows, smooth transitions
YES button behavior: reveal message, hide YES/NO after 1s, trigger soft confetti effect lasting ~10s, and show heart-shower background behind the revealed message

NO button behavior: on each click it jumps to a new position in a loop until YES is clicked; also change soft gradient background colors and update puppy image to progressively sadder variants per NO click
On the YES reveal (final message area), replace the sad puppy photo with a happiest puppy image or GIF
Make the sad puppy image sequence on the Valentine invitation screen loop (cycle through sad variants repeatedly rather than stopping at the last image)
Use the exact invitation copy provided: “Mr, Ayan Will You Like To Be My Valentine 2026 ?” with subtitle “on this 14th of feb i wanna be the 1 4 u”
Constrain the jumping/auto-moving NO button so it never goes off-screen (always stays within the viewport) while looping until YES is clicked

Add extra visual polish: pulsing glow outline around the puppy, tiny floating heart bubbles drifting in the background, smooth fade-in for the main question text, a soft shadow under the jumping NO button, and a subtle happy-puppy wiggle/bounce animation

projectName: Responsive Valentine invitation webpage with retry screen, playful YES/NO interactions, confetti, hearts, and puppy mood changes
